images.copyright: Zion National Park, Utah, United States (© Simon Dannhauer/Getty Images)
images.title: Utah's first national park
images.caption: Zion National Park, Utah, United States
images.desc: Standing in Zion National Park in Utah, United States, it is impossible not to feel small. Massive sandstone cliffs, sculpted over millions of years, rise towards the sky. It became a national park in 1919, but its history stretches much further back. The Ancestral Puebloans and later the Southern Paiute people lived here, relying on the Virgin River. Evidence of their presence remains in petroglyphs and archaeological sites. Today, the river continues to carve through the landscape, creating canyons that attract hikers and climbers.

images.copyright: Hot air balloons over Göreme Historical National Park in Cappadocia, Türkiye (© Anton Petrus/Getty Images)
images.title: Celebrating history
images.caption: International Day for Monuments and Sites
images.desc: Imagine a world without the pyramids, the Great Wall or ancient cave cities—hard to picture, right? That's why April 18 is the International Day for Monuments and Sites, an event recognised by UNESCO dedicated to protecting cultural treasures worldwide. This day is all about celebrating our history, raising awareness about endangered sites and making sure future generations can enjoy them too.

og.title: International Day for Monuments and Sites
og.desc: Imagine a world without the pyramids, the Great Wall or ancient cave cities—hard to picture, right? That's why April 18 is the International…

images.copyright: Andean cocks-of-the-rock, Ecuador (© Kit Day/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: Double the drama
images.caption: Andean cocks-of-the-rock, Ecuador
images.desc: If fashion had a bird ambassador, the cock-of-the-rock would steal the spotlight. The males? They look like they're wearing a bright orange-red costume, complete with a huge crest that almost covers their beak. With its bold colours, this native South American bird isn't just about looks—it's got the moves too.

og.title: Andean cocks-of-the-rock, Ecuador

images.copyright: Kachina Bridge, Natural Bridges National Monument, Utah, United States (© Alan Majchrowicz/Getty Images)
images.title: A passage through time
images.caption: Anniversary of Natural Bridges National Monument, Utah, United States
images.desc: Within the remote canyons of southeastern Utah in the United States, Natural Bridges National Monument highlights the power of erosion and the passage of time. Shaped by the relentless forces of wind and water, this monument features three magnificent natural bridges—Sipapu, Kachina and Owachomo. These bridges were named to honour the Ancestral Puebloans who once lived here. Sipapu is the largest bridge, with a massive opening that could almost fit the dome of the United States Capitol. Kachina, pictured here, is equidistant from Sipapu and Owachomo. It was named after the petroglyphs and pictographs found at its base. Owachomo is believed to be the oldest of the three. Its thin, arching structure suggests it may eventually collapse. Today, this monument remains a place of awe and solitude, where visitors can hike beneath the soaring bridges, gaze at some of the darkest night skies in the country and step back into a landscape sculpted over millions of years.

og.title: Anniversary of Natural Bridges National Monument, Utah, United States
og.desc: Within the remote canyons of southeastern Utah in the United States, Natural Bridges National Monument highlights the power of erosion and…

images.copyright: Beach art on Sauveterre Beach by Zarpo, Les Sables-d'Olonne, Vendee, France (© Hemis/Alamy Stock Photo)
images.title: See Art, Do Art, Be Art
images.caption: World Art Day
images.desc: Imagine a world without colour, music or design—how dull would life be? Every April 15, World Art Day reminds us of the beauty, inspiration and culture that art brings into our lives. Established by the International Association of Art in honour of Leonardo da Vinci's birthday, this global celebration promotes creativity in all its forms.

images.copyright: Atlantic spotted dolphins near Santa Maria Island, Azores, Portugal (© Jordi Chias/Minden Pictures)
images.title: The chase begins!
images.caption: Atlantic spotted dolphins
images.desc: Sleek, social and spotted—the Atlantic spotted dolphin is a standout in the ocean. Found mainly in warm, temperate waters of the Atlantic Ocean, these dolphins are known for their unique spotted patterns, which become more visible as they age.

images.copyright: Wat Tang Sai Temple in Ban Krut, Thailand (© Ratnakorn Piyasirisorost/Getty Images)
images.title: Let's celebrate Songkran!
images.caption: Songkran—Thai New Year
images.desc: New Year celebrations don't always come with fireworks—sometimes, they come with buckets and a nationwide water splash fest! Thailand's Songkran festival is a unique mix of spiritual traditions and all-out water fights. Held from April 13 to 15 this year, the holiday is deeply rooted in Buddhist customs and focuses on cleansing and starting afresh. During this time, people visit temples, offer food to monks and pour scented water over Buddha statues and elders' hands as a sign of respect. Meanwhile, the streets turn into water battlegrounds, with locals and tourists alike getting soaked in the spirit of renewal. Traditional parades roll through the lanes, and in some places, the 'Lady Songkran' or 'Miss Songkran' contest steals the show, with contestants dressed in stunning Thai outfits.

og.title: Songkran—Thai New Year

images.copyright: View from the cupola of the International Space Station above the South Pacific Ocean (© NASA)
images.title: 108 minutes that changed the world
images.caption: International Day of Human Space Flight
images.desc: Not so long ago, humanity took its first step beyond Earth. For thousands of years, we gazed at the stars, dreaming of what lay beyond. Then, on April 12, 1961, one man left the planet and changed history forever. That morning, Soviet pilot Yuri Gagarin climbed into a small, spherical spacecraft named Vostok 1. The countdown began. The engines ignited. As the rocket roared toward the sky, he called out, 'Poyekhali!'—'Let's go!' And just like that, Earth had its first space traveller.

og.title: International Day of Human Space Flight
